abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Key lessons focus on: 1) quality at
            entry, as an essential element in project design. It is
            re-emphasized that consultations at preparation, with
            stakeholders, particularly the private sector, facilitates
            the understanding of reforms. Moreover, political risk
            assessments should be adequately reviewed at preparation, to
            consider political realities which may preclude successful
            completion; 2) the need for strong, and consistent
            government commitment, and ownership of the privatization
            program to achieve success; 3) the need for a strong
            privatization agency, supported by skilled staff, and
            empowered with the appropriate authority to implement
            reforms. The Project Unit was not an agency, rather a unit
            under the Ministry of Finance, and was subject to political
            approval, and endorsements, reducing its ability to prod
            reform. Given that institutional capacity is a slow process,
            expectations should be modest, rather, attention should be
            geared towards monitoring, and reporting on the impact of
            privatization. This is paramount to demonstrate that the
            processes are delivering the benefits promised, to maintain
            consensus, and keep up the momentum of reforms; and, 4)
            public awareness, stakeholder participation, and consensus
            approach as essential in policy design, and reform implementation.
